newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Begemann starts B-share listing procedure.
newsitem.headline: Begemann starts B-share listing procedure.

text.p: Industrial investment firm Royal Begemann Groep NV is free to begin listing procedures on the Amsterdam bourse for its controversial B-shares, a spokesman for the Amsterdam stock exchange said on Thursday.

Begemann wants to set up the shares, which it has called "certificates of justice", to give investors the chance to benefit should it win its damages claim against the government and stock exchange in the aftermath of an insider trading case.
The company last June said it would claim 900 million guilders in damages relating to the failed insider dealing charges against its former chief Joep van den Nieuwenhuyzen.

Former Begemann chairman Van den Nieuwenhuyzen was acquitted last year of insider trading in the so-called HCS affair. He has laid a separate 300 million guilder claim for the personal damage he suffered during the affair.

"The B-shares were created as part of the Bega-claim against the government and the Amsterdam stock exchange because of the affair which took place regarding Mr. Van den Nieuwenhuyzen," Begemann spokeswoman Wilke van Thiel said.
"These shares give the shareholders the right to money arising from the claims," she said. "If there's money paid on these claims then it goes directly to the shareholders."

Van Thiel said shareholders would be entitled to one B-share for every existing share they held as a retrospective interim dividend payment. The company paid no interim dividend when it reported a first half net profit of 14.2 million guilders in September.

The Amsterdam stock exchange spokesman declined to comment on the nature of the new B-shares but said Begemann could now prepare a prospectus for bourse approval. Van Thiel said she expected a prospectus could be submitted within two months.
"We agreed with Begemann to start the formal procedure to come to a listing," the exchange spokesman said.
He said further questions would need to be answered before a listing could be finalised. "What exactly are the assets of this stock? Is it an empty shell or is it real?"
Van Thiel said Begemann was still preparing its damages case. "We're working on the case but we don't know when it will be presented, it could take years," she said.
